bibl.title: Letter from [Philip Showalter Hench] to Ralph Cooper Hutchison, October 7, 1940

div1.p: [Hench] reports that Rojas has discovered receipts that prove the site of Camp Lazear. [Hench] would like to buy the site and the building remains for restoration.

div1.head: Letter from [Philip Showalter Hench] to Ralph Cooper Hutchison, October 7, 1940
div1.p:
Have you warned Dr. Sawyer not to make his talk too professional? Physicians
are so used to giving medical talks that sometimes they forget the nature of their
audience. This morning I had a letter from Dr. Sawyer, suggesting that I tell the story
of the work of the Yellow Fever Commission and that he would “limit himself largely to
an account of the subsequent work in yellow fever which developed from the historic in-
vestigations of the commission. I shall therefore avoid giving any narrative account
of the commission's experiments but shall of course need to refer to Dr. Lazear and the
part which he took and the significance of his sacrifice.” The reason that I fear that
he may be planning a talk too technical for your audience is that he has asked my help
on getting from Miss Agramonte some information on one of Dr. Agramonte's monkey experiments.
Unless Sawyer's reference to monkey experiments is very general, I am afraid he is already
getting too highbrow. I suggest that you write to him, saying that you have written to
both of us to keep our talks rather popular. In answering him today, I will not tell him
this although I would like to. If I did, and you wrote him the same thing in a day or
two, he might know the source of the suggestion and it should come from you, not me.

We have made a new discovery. Miss Rojas has discovered her father's old
journal-cash book with notations as to the rent money received from “Major Mr. Reed” and
later from “Major J. R. Kean” who acted as Reed's disbursing quartermaster officer.
I am having these photographed and translated, and attested too. This should be the last
straw to break down the resistance of the Cuban authorities. An airmail from Moran last
night gave me more dope on this and also tells me that his further investigation of one of
the shacks which we visited makes him feel that it is the remains of Building No. 1 with
an extra lean-to and certain other changes. Don't accept this as final. I can't. But the
inside of the shack has grooved and tongued boards as described by Reed, it does face the
right direction, I believe, and may in truth be the remnants. I am quietly suggesting that
they sound out the cost for an option. My own valuation of it would be about $300 or $400
for the shack and land, and I should be willing to buy it myself promptly to protect it
and later campaign myself among interested physicians and institutions in America for money
for its restoration. Keep this quiet or I will have, not only competition in buying it,
but they may raise its price beyond all reason. Furthermore, I am not sure that it is the
building.
